experience: You and Rich both know Matt Greene, Steven Aldrich, and 124 others
In modern People Ops organizations, you don't "get" a seat at the table--you earn one. But ask anyone in HR what they want and they'll often say "a seat at the table."
Feeling stuck? Here's a few ways to earn that seat.
1) Be proactive versus reactive--build programs that reflect where the business is going not where it’s historically been.
2) Kill sacred cows--the traditions and ideas that got you where you are may not get you where you need to go. Be willing to let go of anything that doesn’t get you to future state.
3) Ask for harsh feedback--don’t ask what’s working; ask what isn’t. Fix it. 4) Embrace transparency--share metrics that feel uncomfortable but drive better conversations.
5) Leave your desk-your team has to be in the business to understand, live and breathe it--you can’t learn that sitting solely in the HR department.
6) Lead don’t follow--HR teams are too often order takers versus movers and shakers--build a team of people with a bias to act and lead versus observe and follow.
How is your people team earning a seat at your organization? How should they?

Senior Director, Customer Care Employee Experience

I work with a high energy team of Internet consultant leaders. These folks are scrappy and dedicated to making the lives of our customers better with every interaction. My responsibilities include site leadership, employee engagement, talent management, strategic planning and execution to drive business attainment. I also had the unique opportunity to join forces with our design/construction partners during a full-renovation of our Hiawatha, Iowa facility. My passion is building high performing teams with engaged leaders that provide amazing experiences for our employees and customers.

I consult with teams throughout the company to build stronger leaders and more scalable functions. It's a great experience because I work with such a wide variety of experiences. The collaboration as a part of my work is tremendously rewarding.During this assignment, I reorganized a core product support department from director level down to provide an updated customer and employee experience. Outcomes: Email response service levels reduced from 6+ days to under 6 hours; core functions were realigned to new parent departments to provide better employee and customer experience; ensured gender pay parity as appropriate; assessed leadership capabilities and reassigned as necessary.
Director, Customer Care Talent Acquisition & Staffing Operations

Go Daddy’s vision is to radically shift the global economy toward small business by empowering people to easily start, confidently grow and successfully run their own ventures. We're in search of amazingly passionate & skilled people to help our customers Kick Ass! Ask me about it or check out GoDaddy.com/Careers for more.Outcomes: Established a metrics-driven methodology for assessing source and recruiter effectiveness; hired 1350+ Customer Consultants in 2014 with over 450 in Q4 with a team of 4 recruiters; updated our applicant tracking system (Jobvite); updated our high-volume screening process to improve technical and sales aptitude; assisted in educating our Care leaders in behavior-based interview practices

Responsible for the engagement and performance of ~750 internet consultants as well as 60+ front-line leaders. I spent the majority of my time focused on creating a consistent experience for all Customer Care team members across departments. Examples include evaluating absentee reasons, compensation structures and coaching processes. During my tenure in this role, I represented Go Daddy at the 2013 ACCE as a panelist discussing employee engagement.
Panel judge for some of the country's brightest young people in the website design category. This year's theme was leadership and legacy.

June 22, 2015, Rich worked with Tyler in the same group

I had the honor and privilege of working with Rich during his time serving GoDaddy as Director, Customer Care Talent Acquisition & Staffing Operations.  I can genuinely say that Rich is one of the most inspiring people I have ever had the opportunity to work with.  His professional demeanor, team spirit, thirst for knowledge and genuine care for everyone who works with him was evident in every encounter.  Rich worked tirelessly to ensure everyone around him reached their optimal potential and above and beyond that he has proven to be one of the best friends and allies I have encountered in my career.  During some of the most challenging situations, Rich served as a beckon of hope and as a template for how to truly lead through his authentic care and concern for those around him.  Rich is a staple at GoDaddy and in large part our company’s growth and success can be linked to him and his years working to develop a world class company culture.  Rich Van Meter is not only someone I highly recommend professionally, but he is also a stellar person who I would I stand by in any situation.

VP of Human Resources - Talent, Technology and Insights
March 24, 2015, Andrew managed Rich directly

I teach hiring managers all the time the difference between hiring smart, capable and motivated people vs. trying to find the "ideal" candidate.  Rich was the first person I ever managed that taught me this lesson.  Rich did not come from staffing but managed a critical part our staffing function on the Sales and Support side.  He came from the Sales and Support organization to help rebuild the relationship between staffing and the business and improve our hiring capabilities during a time of hyper-growth.  Rich has exceptional communication, management and leadership skills.  His insights in to the staffing function were very refreshing.  He asked the right questions and came to the right conclusions because he was focused on business outcomes, not transactions.  Rich has a great sense for process and gets in to the reporting details.  This level of detail and reporting acumen is where we are trying to take the entire function.    Great people get tapped and Rich is a great person.  I am really going to miss Rich but excited he is staying with the company and we will have an opportunity to continue to Join Forces.

September 30, 2015, Rich reported directly to Andrew

I’ve worked closely for or with Andrew for more than a year. He’s deeply passionate about his craft and is a hands-on leader in more than just his talent acquisition space. In many ways, he acts as a positive disruptor with his team and among his peer group to challenge existing paradigms for the right reasons. His outlooks on family, life and work are all-in. He challenges people to consistently raise the talent bar and empowers his team to innovate.I don’t often use the term mentor but with Andrew, it fits. He has an honest way of teaching people that are willing to learn. He’s candid, methodical and hands-off. Andrew paints a clear vision and then gets out of the way so that his people can get there.

summary: I’ll work with anyone dedicated to making a difference in a cause greater than themselves. I believe that, in my own way, I can help change the world, one person at a time.Growing leaders and aligning potential with results gets me fired up. I enjoy digging in and improving process through people and alignment of great values. The right mix of both results in positive experiences and results for customers and employees.My family drives my focus and I enjoy the simple things in life with them like a backyard BBQ, a road trip or a family game night.
